Subject: Request for Overleaf link of Data Analysis book
Text:
Mime-Version: 1.0

Hey there,

Someone just submitted your form on gabors-data-analysis.com/. Here's what =
they had to say:


name:
Denis Pascal de Crombrugghe


_replyto:
denis.decrombrugghe@nu.edu.kz


type:
other


message:
Some time ago I made some comments about the book. I have now received an e=
xamination copy and read more. There are two more comments I want to make, =
in case you are still willing to consider them for your second edition. The=
y concern the distinction between sample and population entities.=20
(1) There is no sharp distinction between the (mathematical) expectation E(=
x) and the sample average \bar(x). The term "expectation" does not =
even appear in the index. This is regrettable. (The comment generalises to =
further moments.)=20
(2) Similarly there not a sharp distinction between (population) parameter =
and (sample) statistic. The term "parameter" appears briefly in Ch.=
 3 only. In Ch. 6 it is replaced by the phrase "true value of statistic=
" which in my view is nonsense. (A test statistic, for example, does no=
t have a "true value".)=20
Please let me know if it makes sense to make more comments later in the sum=
mer. It seems to me an effort in conceptual and terminological accuracy cou=
ld make your book even better than it already is!=20
Thanks for reading,
;Denis

Subject: Data Analysis/ overleaf
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Dear Gabor,

Thanks for making sure I (finally) received a copy of the book. I was
reading excerpts and just tried to send the following comments to you via
the book's website, so maybe this mail is a repetition, in which case I
apologise.

There are two more comments I want to make, in case you are still willing
to consider them for your second edition. They concern the distinction
between sample and population entities.
(1) There is no sharp distinction between the (mathematical) expectation
E(x) and the sample average \bar(x). The term "expectation" does not even
appear in the index. This is regrettable. (The comment generalises to
further moments.)
(2) Similarly there is not a sharp distinction between (population)
parameter and (sample) statistic. The term "parameter" appears briefly in
Ch. 3 only. In Ch. 6 it is replaced by the phrase "true value of the
statistic" which in my view is nonsense. (A test statistic, for example,
does not have a "true value".)

Please let me know if it makes sense to make more comments later in the
summer. It seems to me an effort in conceptual and terminological accuracy
could make your book even better than it already is!

Thanks for reading,
;Denis

> I guess because of customs issues. The only time I managed to get a book
> through customs here in Kazakhstan is when I had a tracking number that
> allowed me to pay a specialised company to go and get the book through, a=
nd
> that took weeks. Since Brexit, even getting books from GB into Belgium is
> not easy; you have to be there to pay import duties or the book is sent
> back after a few days. Related to this, is an electronic version of the
> book available or planned?
>
> Concerning LASSO, yes indeed, standardising the predictors is a way to
> deal with the fact that ordinary LASSO outcomes can be sensitive to
> different scalings among the predictors.
>
> If I get a chance to use the book for courses in the coming year(s) you
> will definitely get more comments... Perhaps even more than you care for!
> Cheers,
> ;Denis

Subject: Re: 2nd ed --- Re: New submission from Gabors Website Contact
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Dear G=C3=A1bor,

Thank you very much for writing to CUP. What a wonderful reactivity! I did
request an inspection copy when the book came out, but it never arrived --
I guess because of customs issues. The only time I managed to get a book
through customs here in Kazakhstan is when I had a tracking number that
allowed me to pay a specialised company to go and get the book through, and
that took weeks. Since Brexit, even getting books from GB into Belgium is
not easy; you have to be there to pay import duties or the book is sent
back after a few days. Related to this, is an electronic version of the
book available or planned?

Concerning LASSO, yes indeed, standardising the predictors is a way to deal
with the fact that ordinary LASSO outcomes can be sensitive to different
scalings among the predictors.

If I get a chance to use the book for courses in the coming year(s) you
will definitely get more comments... Perhaps even more than you care for!
Cheers,
;Denis

Subject: Re: 2nd ed --- Re: New submission from Gabors Website Contact
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Thanks Denis!

I wrote to CUP to get you a copy.
In any case great suggestions for the 2nd ed.

One of our aims was to keep to talk about stuff that matters for
practitioners outside of phd. But, it seems a bit more stats is needed, so
I plan to add bits. Some of your suggestions also go that direction like
t-distribution or consistency. Other suggestions are great. For example
test of unit elasticity i'll certainly take.

I am planning adding standardized variables for prediction before lasso,
not sure this is what you meant.

Thanks a lot, and keep comments coming:-)

Gabor

Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Welcome to the OSF User Engagement Group!

View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/7400db11cd3b/welcome-t=
o-the-osf-user-engagement-group?e=3Deb5100a127)

Hi there!

Welcome to the OSF User Engagement Group! =F0=9F=8E=89

You're receiving this email because=2C in the past=2C you've expressed int=
erest in participating and providing feedback on potential and upcoming OS=
F features. We greatly appreciate your willingness to contribute to shapin=
g the OSF platform to better meet your needs and the needs of your communi=
ty.

We're excited to announce our upcoming session focused on a new registrati=
on template aimed at enhancing data archiving and sharing on the OSF platf=
orm. This initiative is in response to recent mandates from the White Hous=
e requiring federally funded studies to openly share their data.

To kick us off=2C we have a survey to gather your perspectives and opinion=
s on data sharing before the session. We will then host a focus group disc=
ussion on the registration template itself. Details of the focus group are=
 provided below. To participate in the survey and RSVP for the focus group=
=2C click the button at the bottom of this email.

Focus Group Details:
* Date: April 19th
* Time: 11:00am Eastern Time
* Duration: Approximately 1 hour

Your input in this session will be invaluable as we work towards improving=
 data sharing capabilities on the OSF platform.

If you have any questions or need further information=2C feel free to reac=
h out to Daniel at . We're here to help!

If you prefer not to receive further communications about the OSF User Eng=
agement Group=2C you can simply click unsubscribe at any time.

Thank you once again for your interest and participation.

Be on the lookout for more sessions for a wider range of time zones in the=
 near future!

Hi,

Have you noticed that self-care seems to be a luxury reserved for the privi=
leged? Even self-care practices that don=E2=80=99t cost a lot of money stil=
l require time that some people just aren=E2=80=99t able to spare.

I=E2=80=99ve been giving this a lot of thought lately, and I=E2=80=99ve com=
e up with some great ways for those who are overworked and underpaid to wor=
k self-care into their lives without sacrificing a lot of time or money. I=
=E2=80=99d love to put together an article on how to make self-care accessi=
ble for everyone. I'd also be happy to feature your website within the =
piece!

If you think this type of piece is a good fit for your site, please let me =
know, and I=E2=80=99ll get started on a (free!) article for you!

Thank you!
Emma Grace Brown
Emmagracebrown.com

Dear Prof. Gabor Bekes
I hope you are doing well.
I am Ibrahim alnafrah, a lecturer at Damascus University.
I am impressed with your book "Data analysis for Business, Economics, and
Policy". So, I intend to use it for teaching data analysis in economics.
It would be highly appreciated if you share with me the slides and
solution manual.
Best regards and many thanks in advance.

Subject: Fwd: Slides for teaching Data analysis for Business, Economics, and Policy
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Dear Gabors,
I am in the process of moving institutions to Humboldt University Berlin wh=
ere I will be teaching the econometrics intro course and a follow up applie=
d econometrics course (each taking one semester) at the econ department. Th=
e audience will be hundreds of students across business, econ, stats. In th=
is context, I have browsed an inspection copy of your book and I am deeply =
impressed. The idea of building the book around concrete case studies, with=
 data, codes, and suggested exercises is great. It is perfect for these app=
lied courses where my primary goal is to get students get to work with data=
 (there will be other courses concerned with methods). Having the TEX files=
 of your lectures would be an enormous help in preparing the course materia=
ls, so I was wondering if you were willing to share them.
Best,
Gabriel


PROF GABRIEL M AHLFELDT
PROFESSOR OF URBAN ECONOMICS AND LAND DEVELOPMENT
DIRECTOR MSC REAL ESTATE ECONOMICS AND FINANCE
EDITOR REGIONAL SCIENCE AND URBAN ECONOMICS
LONDON SCHOOL OF ECONOMICS
www.ahlfeldt.com<http://www.ahlfeldt.com/> | www.twitter.com/ahlfeldt<http:=
//www.twitter.com/ahlfeldt>

Dear Professor,

My name is Ahmed Tritah, and I am a professor at the University of Poitiers=

ometrics/data science and the impact evaluation of public policy. I am plan=

Text:
Dear Gabor,

I'm currently using your textbook, Data Analysis, and I appreciate your
valuable contributions.

I'm reaching out regarding the 'hotels-vienna.dta' dataset from the
'da_data_repo' zip file, specifically for Chapter 4. The dataset only
includes data for Vienna, while Exercise #1 on page 115 (Chapter 4) as well
as Exercise #1 (Chapter 3) require data for another city.

Could you share the cleaned dataset for this exercise, including data for
cities other than Vienna? Your assistance is crucial for completing the
exercise as intended.

Thank you for your time and support.

Sincerely,

Manish

Hi Gabor,

Attached is the syllabus for the course where I plan to use your textbook. =
The syllabus is still a work in process, since I will be teaching the cours=
e for the first time starting in January.

nd does not allow us to make the argument that one of the more parsimonious=
 models (M3 or M4) is better than, M5. I wanted to get your thoughts on thi=
s.

Thank you,
Simona

Celebrating 500=2C000 OSF Users!

Hi G=C3=A1bor=2C

We=E2=80=99re thrilled to announce that the OSF community has reached 500=
=2C000 worldwide registered users (https://www.cos.io/blog/celebrating-a-g=
lobal-open-science-community) ! OSF=E2=80=99s users are leading by example=
 in improving research openness=2C integrity=2C and reproducibility. Your=
 adoption is having a viral impact=2C as indicated by OSF=E2=80=99s non-li=
near growth every year since it launched in November 2012. It took five ye=
ars to reach the first 100=2C000 users=2C two more years to reach 200=2C00=
0=2C and one more year to reach 400=2C000. Now=2C just seven months later=
=2C half a million researchers are using OSF.

https://youtu.be/udcp3Nuat4w
Watch the video to hear from members of the OSF user community.

You make it possible. Our team is proud to be serving the research communi=
ty with a free=2C open-source research collaboration and management platfo=
rm that enables open science practices. Thank you for your contributions t=
o improving the research culture.

PS: Join us today for a webinar (https://www.cos.io/events)  highlighting=
 how OSF can support your open science practices and solve common problems=
 many researchers face throughout the research lifecycle.


** Improve Your Research Rigor and Earn Open Practice Badges

Subject: Re: hotels-vienna Dataset with the Data Analysis textbook
hotels-vienna Dataset with the Data Analysis textbook
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Tips and tricks for understanding the OSF

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/osf-tips-mar-1387568?e=3Deb5100a127)
In the dynamic world of research=2C the standardization and interoperabili=
ty of data have become crucial for advancing scientific discovery. As rese=
arch communities grow and diversify=2C the need for a unified approach to=
 metadata=E2=80=94the data that provides information about other data=E2=
=80=94has never been more apparent. Addressing this challenge=2C the OSF h=
as taken a significant step forward by integrating the CEDAR Embeddable Ed=
itor=2C a move that promises to revolutionize the way metadata standards f=
rom various research communities are managed and utilized.
Metadata plays a foundational role in research=2C offering the context nec=
essary for understanding=2C replicating=2C and building upon existing stud=
ies. However=2C the heterogeneity of metadata standards across different d=
isciplines has often led to silos=2C making it difficult to share and comp=
are data effectively. Recognizing this issue=2C the Center for Expanded Da=
ta Annotation and Retrieval (CEDAR) (https://metadatacenter.org?utm_source=
=3Dosfgenearl_enl&utm_medium=3Demail&utm_campaign=3Dtipstricks_may) develo=
ped the Embeddable Editor=E2=80=94a tool designed to simplify the creation=
=2C management=2C and sharing of standardized metadata.


** OSF and CEDAR: A Strategic Integration

Al=C3=A1bb kiemelt=C3=BCk a legfontosabb v=C3=A1ltoz=C3=A1sokat:

orm=C3=A1lis vitarendez=C3=A9si folyamatunkat, valamint a v=C3=A1lasztottb=

nk az=C3=A9rt, hogy mindig =C3=B6r=C3=B6mmel haszn=C3=A1ld a Discordot, =C3=
=A9s rem=C3=A9lj=C3=BCk, hogy sosem mer=C3=BCl fel vit=C3=A1s helyzet!

esebb t=C3=A1j=C3=A9koztat=C3=A1st ny=C3=BAjtunk az adatv=C3=A9delmi jogaid=
r=C3=B3l, valamint ezek gyakorl=C3=A1s=C3=A1r=C3=B3l. Aktualiz=C3=A1ltuk to=
v=C3=A1bb=C3=A1 az =C3=A1ltalunk gy=C5=B1jt=C3=B6tt adatokat, valamint azt,=
 hogy mire haszn=C3=A1ljuk =C5=91ket. Az adataid v=C3=A9delme fontos sz=C3=
=A1munkra, =C3=A9s igyeksz=C3=BCnk korl=C3=A1tozni a gy=C5=B1jt=C3=B6tt ada=

z adataid v=C3=A9delme felett a Discordon.

b kontextust osztottunk meg, =C3=A9s =C3=A9rthet=C5=91bb=C3=A9 tett=C3=BCk =
az ir=C3=A1nyelveinket.  =20

message:
In the first chapter where data and information are introduced, I think the=
 introduction is not that clear. In information theory, these are more stri=
ctly defined. I think there information is encoded into data, and data is t=
ransformed into data. (via encryption, or for a noisy channel, not informat=
ion being transformed into data). I think in this sense data is abundant an=
d information is scarce. So I think "information is is considered data =
if its content is based on measurement" does not align with this. I don=
't think it is necessarly bad, but it would be nice, if the book did a =
shoutout, (as it usually does super well), if some other fields do this way=
. We will use it like this.

Hey there,

Someone just submitted your form on gabors-data-analysis.com/. Here's what =
they had to say:


name:
Frank Qu


_replyto:
qu@nju.edu.cn


type:
resource


message:
Dear Professor Bekes and Kezdi,
I am writing to ask for LaTex resources to make Beamer Slides for my teachi=
ng. My name is Frank Qu, and I am an economics professor at Nanjing Univers=
ity, China. Your book is an exciting textbook covering basic statistics, ca=
usal inference, and machine learning methods with many good examples and re=
plicating exercises. I have been looking for such a brilliant textbook for =
my teaching. Now here it is. I will use it as one of the supplementary text=
books in an econometrics course for undergraduate students in Economics and=
 a Big Data Analytics course for MBA students.
And following the info on the website of Cambridge University Press, I also=
 found the company website. It is another treasure with many valuable resou=
rces except for one, Latex or Rmarkdown files for making slides.

Therefore, I am reaching out to ask if you could kindly share these files w=
ith me. They would be very helpful for my teaching slides. If it is possibl=
e, I would greatly appreciate it. I will also give credit to you on my slid=
es.

Lastly, I also want to express my appreciation for your effort and dedicati=
on in creating this textbook. Your book will be a valuable asset in my teac=
hing. Thank you for your time and consideration.


Yours sincerely,

Frank Qu=20

on support for linear regression.  Are covariate balance and common support=
 essentially accomplishing the same thing?   One checks the distribution of=
 Z variables and the other checks the range of Z variables.  It would seem =
to me that if we have covariate balance for both treated and untreated, the=
n we would also have common support?   All the chapters before 19 seemed st=
raight forward.  Chapters 19+ seem much harder to follow.=20

Subject: New submission from Gabors Website Contact
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Now you can create a registration on OSF with or without an existing proje=
ct.

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/improving-research-rigor-just-got-=
quicker-1384976?e=3Deb5100a127)
Introducing a quicker
registration workflow
Hi G=C3=A1bor=2C

Improving the rigor of your research just got quicker! Registrations advan=
ce the quality and transparency of your research=2C increase the credibili=
ty of the results=2C reduce publication bias=2C and help your team plan a=
 study before collecting and analyzing data. Join the thousands of researc=
hers using OSF (https://osf.io/) to register their work=2C and who added o=
ver 22=2C000 new registrations in 2020=2C to increase the rigor and transp=
arency of research.

We=E2=80=99ve made it even easier to register on OSF by adding another opt=
ion to start a registration: Now you can create a registration on OSF with=
 or without an existing project. Both streamlined workflows meet the resea=
rch team where they are =E2=80=94 either working from an existing OSF proj=
ect to build the registration=2C or starting with the registration=2C whic=
h then generates a connected OSF project where you can show and share your=
 work transparently throughout the research lifecycle.

See how to create a new registration without a project >> (https://help.os=
f.io/hc/en-us/articles/1500005273721-Start-a-Registration)
This streamlined registration process also provides research groups with w=
orkflows to enable open practices for their community members. Researchers=
 in governance and politics are advancing their rigor and transparency by=
 preregistering their research on the EGAP Registry (https://osf.io/regist=
ries/egap/discover) .

=E2=80=9CThe new workflow will allow our community of researchers and eval=
uation professionals to preregister research designs with fewer steps. We=
 anticipate that this increased efficiency will lower perceived barriers t=
o preregistration=2C and will help us encourage scholars of governance and=
 politics to increase the rigor and transparency of their work through the=
 practice of registration.=E2=80=9D =E2=80=94 Matthew Lisiecki=2C Senior M=
ethods Manager at EGAP

Ready to preregister your study plan on OSF?

Get Started (https://osf.io/registries/osf/new)
Visit cos.io/registries (https://www.cos.io/products/osf-registries) to le=
arn more about empowering your research community with customized registra=
tion workflows and templates.

ize the book due to lack of access to the accompanying data. Despite my eff=
orts to seek support from the publisher and attempts on Github, I was unsuc=
cessful in obtaining the relevant data sets.

ated with this book. This would enable me to maximize the learning experien=
ce for my students.

s and 6EC511 Econometrics modules. I am happy to share the module handbook =
with you, but I would like to confirm that it is acceptable to do so, as it=
 is not intended for public distribution. My 5EC510 is a second year UG  Ec=
onomics and Finance module., and 6EC512 Econometrics is  a third year UG  E=
conomics and Finance module.  Please let me know your thoughts.

Best wishes,

Leon Stonies

=?UTF-8?B?S2loYWd5dMOhbCDDvHplbmV0ZWtldA==?= itt: The Code Block
Text:
Mime-Version: 1.0

Hey there,

Someone just submitted your form on gabors-data-analysis.com/. Here's what =
they had to say:


name:
Peter Fuleky


_replyto:
fuleky@hawaii.edu


type:
error


message:
Top of page 216 states: "Note that when we estimate a spline, a2 is aut=
omatically calculated as a2 =3D a1 + b1k." That in conjunction with equ=
ation 8.1 would imply that for x =3D k, y =3D a1 + a1 + b1k + b2k. That doe=
s not seem right. At x =3D k, y =3D a1 + b1k and also y =3D a1 + a2 + b2k d=
ue to continuity. Equating the right hand sides implies that a2 =3D (b1-b2)=
k.

Subject: New submission from Gabors Website Contact
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Dear Gabor,

Thank you so much for your reply. I had requested an examination copy of
the book. And this is the response I received from CUP" :

"Thank you for your recent sample copy request. Unfortunately, *Data
Analysis for Business, Economics, and Policy*
<https://click.updates.cambridge.org/?qs=3D31b1795eda74a65d96bbfbe97a86b5e7=
73e8c8c5078bead1b71f5c9baaf7c2fd182f7452c77bac9b5a79b1b1b5ded3e0738ee5e5a14=
0e22d1a32406a4640ef91>
is
currently out of stock or not yet published. Once it is back in stock we
will let you know and have a copy sent out to you. If you wish to
communicate directly with a sales representative, please contact us at
collegesales@cambridge.org.
Best Wishes,
*Higher Education*
Cambridge University Press"

I sent an email to the sales rep but did not get any response.  When I try
to access an approval for accessing instructor resources online, I am
receiving an error message. So, I greatly appreciate your help.
Thank you.

Submitted 11:02 AM - 27 November 2020

Subject: OSF Notifications
Text:
Mime-Version: 1.0

Hey there,

Someone just submitted your form on gabors-data-analysis.com/. Here's what =
they had to say:


name:
Denis Pascal de Crombrugghe


_replyto:
denis.decrombrugghe@nu.edu.kz


type:
other


message:
I like the book a lot. It demystifies many concepts very well. I didn't=
 have a hance to use it (yet) because it was unavailable to me and my stude=
nts (in Kazakhstan). I am going to list a few suggestions here.=20
A general comment is that the value of the book as a reference would increa=
se by simply and briefly placing in context stuff that is absent now and ca=
nnot be found in the index or in the table of contents. For example, nowher=
e do you mention the *Student t distribution*, or explain the difference be=
tween unbiasedness and *consistency* (even though you introduce probability=
 limits). You mention the PP test for unit roots, but not the *ADF test*, w=
hich is even more widespread in practice. In the panel data chapter, you co=
uld mention (not elaborate) *RE models* to complete the range of possible a=
pproaches.=20
- Ch. 6: Why not briefly mention the Student-t distribution and explain why=
 it is not used further in the book (and hardly in practice).=20
- Ch. 9: Please show examples of other null hypotheses than that a coeffici=
ent is zero; in other words, please show other tests than significance test=
s. Examples: a unit (income) elasticity, or constant returns to scale.=20
- Section 9.U2: Introduce the difference between unbiasedness and consisten=
cy.=20
- Ch. 11, Section 11.4: Reducing "Marginal Differences" to their av=
erage is a misleading simplification. Point out that MEs (or "MDs")=
 are individual; they are not constant across observations but variable, sp=
ecific to each individual. Suggest to report a range of variation (e.g. a 9=
0% range, from 5th to 95th percentile). =20
-Ch. 12: Show that simple graphs can help detect autocorrelation, even thou=
gh formal testing is harder: time graphs of residuals and scatters of resid=
uals on their lag. Mention Error Correction Models (ECMs), not a difficult =
topic at all!=20
- Ch. 12, Section 12.U1: point out that under the null of a unit root the o=
rdinary t-test is invalid (that its distribution has been found by simulati=
on to shift to the left and become skewed). Also mention the ADF test, so t=
hat students can find it in context.=20
- Ch. 14 (14.8): LASSO: mention the importance in practice of a comparable =
scaling of the regressor variables!
- Ch. 19 (19.6): Mention that ATET is also often abbreviated ATT.=20
- Ch. 20: you keep mentioning "the inverse normal distribution", as=
 if it were a separate distribution. Would it not be more accurate to speak=
 of the quantile function? You could easily introduce it at the same time a=
s percentiles.=20
- Ch. 23 Panels: in a brief "under the hood" way, also introduce RE=
 models (and therefore GLS).=20
Sorry for not being systematic: not having a proper copy of the book makes =
it hard to read everything. Best wishes, ;D

Subject: OSF Notifications
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Today=2C we=E2=80=99ve added robust metadata fields that will make all of=
 your work more discoverable and more clearly described for future reuse.

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/affiliate-your-osf-research-with-u=
md-1386136?e=3Deb5100a127)
New OSF metadata to support data sharing policy compliance

Hi G=C3=A1bor=2C

OSF has always enabled researchers to easily collaborate with their peers=
=2C and demonstrate the value and scientific impact of transparency throug=
hout the research lifecycle. Today=2C we=E2=80=99ve added robust metadata=
 fields that will make all of your work more discoverable and more clearly=
 described for future reuse. It is now easier than ever to signal the rigo=
r=2C openness=2C and value of your data=2C papers=2C materials=2C and to b=
e compliant with funder data sharing policies (https://www.cos.io/blog/how=
-osf-meets-desirable-characteristics-for-data-repositories) .

You can find new metadata fields in your current and new OSF Projects=2C R=
egistrations=2C and even your files! The new fields include:
* Resource type to describe what kind of research material you are sharing=
 (dataset=2C paper=2C image=2C etc)
* Language of your materials
* The name of the funders that have funded or supported your research
* The title of your specific award
* An identifier for your award

Complemented by our existing metadata for title=2C description=2C contribu=
tors=2C license=2C publication and modification dates.

The OSF implements best practices in research metadata while maintaining t=
he flexibility it is known for by supporting multiple funders associated w=
ith one OSF project=2C and by enabling resource type labels for collection=
s of documents or data in your registrations as well as the individual fil=
es within. All of these relationships and more are powered by related iden=
tifiers that the OSF enables to make your work more discoverable and reusa=
ble than ever. For example=2C check out one of the COS replication project=
s (https://osf.io/scayl) =2C which uses all of these in addition to connec=
ting related materials and data through our output sharing workflow (https=
://www.cos.io/blog/badges-for-open-research-practices-available-on-osf-reg=
istrations) .

Find out more about the new metadata features (https://www.cos.io/blog/new=
-osf-metadata-to-support-data-sharing-policy-compliance) and why we priori=
tize them on the OSF=2C and visit OSF Support (https://help.osf.io/article=
/572-metadata-to-increase-discoverability) to find ways to fully leverage=
 your OSF metadata. You can also join COS metadata experts on February 22=
=2C 2023 for our first in a series of events focused on the value and impa=
ct of metadata in open science (https://cos-io.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN=
_W9D5k35BR5mVAkCgBE5ZSA) =2C and stay tuned for subject metadata and index=
ing OSF data in Google Dataset Discovery coming soon.

You can add these metadata to all of your current and new OSF projects=2C=
 registrations=2C and files today. Visit your OSF My Projects page to get=
 started (https://osf.io/myprojects/) !

The Center for Open Science Team

Describing=2C sharing=2C and discovering files on OSF will be deeper=2C fa=
ster=2C and broader than ever.=C2=A0

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/affiliate-your-osf-research-with-u=
md-1385692?e=3Deb5100a127)
Your OSF Files Have a New Look

Hi G=C3=A1bor=2C

OSF has always provided a way for scholars to associate files with preprin=
ts=2C collaborations=2C and research registrations=2C fully contextualizin=
g their research outputs. Now using=2C sharing=2C and discovering files wi=
ll be deeper=2C faster=2C and broader than ever.

We have launched a brand new interface that makes working with files on OS=
F faster and easier.
* OSF files pages now utilizes a =E2=80=9Cflat=E2=80=9D files directory=2C=
 much like popular storage providers Google Drive and Dropbox.
* Focus on each part of your project or registration directory with a file=
s list that loads near instantly.
* Features like moving=2C copying=2C and downloading files are in a stream=
lined toolbar=2C and are available for independent files=2C entire folders=
=2C or even all files stored within a storage provider.
* Select large groups of files from your list using the brand new range se=
lect feature.

Demonstrating the new OSF files browser and file viewer interfaces

The file viewer has been upgraded as well!
* More screen area for you to display and interact with your files.
* Download and share features are easy to find=2C and a new toolbar enable=
s users to quickly tag their files for increased discoverability.
* The OSF commitment to transparent workflows is still our priority=2C so=
 the file version history is available in its entirety in the toolbar.
* Render or download any version of the file in the browser.

Find out more about additional features coming soon for OSF files on the C=
OS blog (https://www.cos.io/blog/new-frontiers-for-files-on-osf) =2C and v=
isit OSF Support (https://help.osf.io/article/387-project-files) to find w=
ays to fully leverage your OSF files pages.


The Center for Open Science Team

ights and how they are exercised. We also updated what data we collect and =

rivacy on Discord.

ace where everyone can find a place to belong. We've added more context and=

s.

instructor on the publisher=E2=80=99s site.

Analysis for Economics and Finance (ECON 2204). There is no public =

(similar to D2L). The course description can be found here =
<https://wss.uwinnipeg.ca/Student/Courses>; however, you have to search =
for the course. To save you time, I have attached a photo of the =
description.=20

Tip 1. Leverage Metadata to Enhance Discoverability

By adding detailed and relevant metadata to your preregistration=2C you in=

ify for a DOI.

7c2776e53a62167&id=3De94f588a3c&e=3Deb5100a127)

Open Practice Badges help to immediately convey the depth and reliability=
 of your research=2C encouraging more clicks.

hat provide a comprehensive=2C easy-to-navigate view of the complete resea=
rch story.

Try This: Make sure your preregistration is well-connected across lifecycl=
e elements.

2d63bcf7c2776e53a62167&id=3D42e2e0072a&e=3Deb5100a127)

ur preregistration being seen=2C clicked on=2C and cited by the broader re=

Subject: OSF Notifications
=?UTF-8?B?w5pqIGJlamVsZW50a2V6w6k=?=
OSF Notifications
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Tips and tricks for understanding the OSF

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/osf-tips-mar-1386948?e=3Deb5100a127)

OSF projects provide a flexible environment for researchers and their team=
s to dynamically collaborate on=2C organize=2C contextualize=2C integrate=
=2C store=2C and share research processes and outputs. Developing your pro=
ject directory can make your work more accessible=2C discoverable=2C and p=
ersistent.

Components are essentially sub-projects within your main OSF project. They=
 can have their own collaborators=2C files=2C wiki pages=2C DOIs=2C permis=
sions=2C and even their own child components. This hierarchical structure=
 is incredibly useful for breaking down your project into manageable=2C or=
ganized parts.

Read on to see how to make the most of it.
1. Segment Your Project by Research Phase or Type
Organize your project into components based on phases of your research (e.=
g.=2C Literature Review=2C Methodology=2C Data Collection=2C Analysis) or=
 by types of materials (e.g.=2C Datasets=2C Code=2C Manuscripts). This seg=
mentation makes it easier for team members to find relevant materials and=
 understand the project's progress.

2. Assign Specific Collaborators to Components
If your project involves a team=2C you can assign collaborators to specifi=
c components where their expertise is most needed. This ensures that team=
 members have access to the materials they need without being overwhelmed=
 by irrelevant files=2C and it helps to safeguard sensitive data. Start wi=
th viewing the component you would like to assign a specific contributor a=
nd use this help guide (https://help.osf.io/article/247-add-contributors-t=
o-projects-and-components) .

3. Use Components for Pilot Studies or Supplementary Analyses
For projects that include pilot studies or multiple analyses=2C create sep=
arate components for each. This keeps your main project organized and allo=
ws for distinct documentation of methodologies and results=2C which is cru=
cial for transparency and reproducibility.

4. Document Your Process in Component Wikis
Each component can have its own wiki (https://help.osf.io/article/389-wiki=
) . Use this feature to document methodologies=2C decisions=2C and changes=
 specific to that component's focus. This can be invaluable for onboarding=
 new team members and providing context for external collaborators or revi=
ewers.

5. Leverage Differential Access Settings for Targeted Sharing
Components can be made public or private independently of the main project=
 and each other. Use this to your advantage by keeping preliminary data or=
 sensitive information private while sharing more general research outputs=
 or datasets. This selective sharing is crucial for adhering to ethical gu=
idelines and protecting participant confidentiality. For more information=
=2C see Understanding Contributor Permissions (https://help.osf.io/article=
/246-understand-contributor-permissions) .

6. Nested Components for Complex Projects
For particularly complex projects=2C you can create nested components (com=
ponents within components) to mirror the structure of your research even m=
ore closely. This can help in managing large datasets or multifaceted stud=
ies where different datasets or analyses are interrelated.

By effectively using components=2C you not only enhance the organization a=
nd navigability of your projects but also bolster collaboration and the tr=
ansparent sharing of your research process. This approach allows you to ma=
nage large=2C multifaceted research projects with ease while ensuring that=
 all aspects of your work are documented and accessible for future referen=
ce=2C replication=2C or extension by the research community. If you haven'=
t already=2C check out our previous tip on creating a project from example=
 templates (https://help.osf.io/article/585-templates-getting-started-on-o=
sf-faster-and-easier)  and increasing discoverability using persistent ide=
ntifiers (https://help.osf.io/article/577-connecting-pids-for-a-persistent=
-complete-research-story) .

Want to learn more about using OSF to support sharing and discovery of you=
r research? Check out our upcoming OSF webinars!
https://cos-io.zoom.us/webinar/register/4017101923016/WN_UUBwCFleS-auwOT4S=
HTkRQ
Getting Started on the OSF: A Hands-on Guide
March 18 at 11 am ET

This webinar explores a variety of use cases highlighting how OSF can supp=
ort your open science practices and solve common problems many researchers=
 face throughout the research lifecycle=2C while also providing a guided t=
our through key workflows and features.

Sign up (https://cos-io.zoom.us/webinar/register/4017101923016/WN_UUBwCFle=
S-auwOT4SHTkRQ)

https://cos-io.zoom.us/webinar/register/9717101927113/WN_d4zoVgkjTf-2LquGI=
gTN3Q
OSF for Institutions: Tools and Insights for Academic Librarians and Resea=
rch Support Staff
March 27 at 1 pm ET

Discover how OSF Institutions (https://www.cos.io/products/osf-institution=
s) streamlines workflows=2C enhances collaboration for your research commu=
nities=2C and ensures compliance with institutional policies. Learn to tra=
ck research activity=2C improve efficiency=2C and elevate your institution=
=E2=80=99s scholarly outputs.

Sign up (https://cos-io.zoom.us/webinar/register/9717101927113/WN_d4zoVgkj=
Tf-2LquGIgTN3Q)

The Community Pulse provides opportunities to participate in OSF feature t=
esting=2C requests for new features=2C and engaging directly with exceptio=
nal OSF users and use cases. If you would like to participate in a future=
 Community Pulse=2C please reach out to Daniel (daniel@cos.io (mailto:dani=
el@cos.io) ).

We value your input as we continuously strive to enhance our platform to b=
etter serve the research community. Please use the form below to submit yo=
ur ideas and suggestions for new features or improvements to existing ones=
 for OSF Project and Components. Your feedback is invaluable in shaping th=
e future of OSF. Thank you for your contribution! In order to continue imp=
roving these services=2C we would very much appreciate your feedback throu=
gh this short=2C 3-minute survey (https://forms.gle/k9PJ1GNA5FhtPu869) . B=
e on the lookout In the coming month we will sending out a feedback survey=
 for all of the OSF and would love to hear your feedback!


** Stay Connected

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Quick Files will soon be discontinued and the files previously uploaded as=
 Quick Files will be migrated into a public project for each user.

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/affiliate-your-osf-research-with-u=
md-1385583?e=3Deb5100a127)
Quick Files Are Moving

Hi G=C3=A1bor B=C3=A9k=C3=A9s=2C

Since 2018=2C the Quick Files (https://tracking.cirrusinsight.com/abd0926e=
-35a5-45fd-92e3-1f4d0ba9fb6c/help-osf-io-hc-en-us-articles-360019930713-up=
load-quick-files) feature has allowed users to upload public files to the=
 OSF without a project for easy sharing and collaboration.  As OSF continu=
es to develop to meet community needs and infrastructure sustainability=2C=
 Quick Files will be discontinued and the files previously uploaded as Qui=
ck Files will be migrated into a public project for each user on March 11=
=2C 2022.

If you have any Quick Files=2C they are accessible here. (https://tracking=
=2Ecirrusinsight.com/abd0926e-35a5-45fd-92e3-1f4d0ba9fb6c/osf-io-quickfiles)=
  Rest assured=2C your quick files will carefully be moved into a new publ=
ic project=2C where you can continue to view=2C download=2C and share your=
 files. A link to this project will be sent to you when the move is comple=
ted. The links to access the specific files will not change=2C so URLs tha=
t you have shared will continue to work as expected.  If you want to direc=
tly move your Quick Files to an existing project=2C we recommend that you=
 do so before March 11.  You can still move your files between projects la=
ter by linking your projects. For more information=2C see the Link to a Pr=
oject (https://help.osf.io/hc/en-us/articles/360019930313-Link-to-a-Projec=
t) guide. Contact support@osf.io (mailto:support@osf.io?subject=3DQuick%20=
Files%20Sunset) if you have any questions or concerns.

We will be making further improvements including a redesigned file managem=
ent interface with improved file management and navigation=2C the ability=
 to annotate files with Datacite and community developed metadata schemas=
=2C and workflows for connecting the outputs and results of your research=
 across the lifecycle in the coming year.  In the meantime=2C thank you fo=
r partnering with us as a stakeholder in open science and in the success o=
f the infrastructure that helps make it possible!


The Center for Open Science Team

Give your Feedback

We want to hear from you! Sign up (https://forms.gle/ox6wqSLgtxSnv3dt5) to=
 participate in user research and improve the OSF and its upcoming feature=
s!

Subject: OSF Notifications
Text:
Mime-Version: 1.0

Hey there,

Someone just submitted your form on gabors-data-analysis.com/. Here's what =
they had to say:


name:
Madhav Regmi


_replyto:
mregmi@nmsu.edu


type:
resource


message:
Hi,
Starting this fall, I plan to use this textbook for my Intro to Quantitativ=
e Methods course. This is an MS level course of applied/agricultural econom=
ics students at NMSU. I use LaTex/Overleaf, so, I would be grateful if you =
could send me slides/course materials in LaTex/Overleaf format. Also, if po=
ssible, could you please share the teaching resources with me? Thank you fo=
r all your help.

Best,
Madhav Regmi
New Mexico State University



Submitted 02:54 PM - 23 July 2024

Subject: OSF Notifications
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

You can now make transparent updates to your registrations and registratio=
ns are automatically preserved on Internet Archive.

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/affiliate-your-osf-research-with-u=
md-1385500?e=3Deb5100a127)
Registrations are Now Easily Updatable and Preserved on Internet Archive

Hi G=C3=A1bor B=C3=A9k=C3=A9s=2C

We are excited to share with you two recent improvements to the registrati=
on workflow. Registrations are now transparently updates and automatically=
 preserved on Internet Archive.

Updating Registrations

We understand the reality of conducting research where unforeseen circumst=
ances may require research teams to make changes to their research plans.=
 Now researchers can update their registrations to reflect how work was ac=
tually done throughout the research lifecycle through a streamlined  updat=
ing process that focuses on the update=E2=80=99s content and justification=
=2E The increased transparency gives funders and reviewers added clarity on=
 the details and process of your study.

Check out these help guides (https://help.osf.io/hc/en-us/categories/36000=
1550953-Registrations) to learn how to make updates to your registrations!

Tell us what you think of the new workflow by completing this 1-minute sur=
vey (https://forms.gle/gEwfu8Gv3V8Y9vuo8) .

Registration Preservation

Preservation of research outputs is critical to future discovery=2C impact=
 and reuse. Through a partnership with Internet Archive (IA) and funded by=
 the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS)=2C we developed a pip=
eline to digitally preserve registrations=2C their updates=2C and files in=
 IA=E2=80=99s repository. Librarians and institutions can leverage this ne=
w development for the archival and accessibility for their own organizatio=
n. Access your preserved copy through the Internet Archive link provided o=
n your registration.
https://osf.vu.nl/

Give your Feedback

We want to hear from you! Sign up (https://forms.gle/ox6wqSLgtxSnv3dt5) to=
 participate in user research and improve the OSF and its upcoming feature=
s!

Subject: OSF Notifications
Text:
Mime-Version: 1.0

Hey there,

Someone just submitted your form on gabors-data-analysis.com/. Here's what =
they had to say:


name:
Gabor Uhrin


_replyto:
gabor.uhrin@hu-berlin.de


type:
error


message:
K=F6nyv oldal 351. A Newey-West "lag" sz=E1m=E1nak meg=E1llap=EDt=
=E1sa:
- "Lags refer to a way of modeling the structure of serial correlation =
in the dependent variable"
Ez fel=FCletesen igaz is lehet, de szerintem f=E9lrevezet=F6. Illetve sz=E1=
momra azt sugallja, hogy egy AR modellr=F6l van sz=F3 a hibatagra vonatkoz=
=F3an.

 Az eg=E9sz Newey-West dolog arr=F3l sz=F3l, hogy a hibatag hossz=FA t=E1v=
=FA varianci=E1j=E1nak naiv becsl=F6f=FCggv=E9nye (egyszer=FC autokovarianc=
i=E1k becsl=E9se) se nem konzisztens, se nem vezet pozit=EDv (szemi)-defini=
t varianci=E1hoz. Ezt egy s=FAlyozott =E9s csonk=EDtott (truncated) becsl=
=F6fuggv=E9nnyel lehet orvosolni.=20

Helyesebb lenne teh=E1t: "lags are involved in the way the variance of =
the error term is estimated".

A csonk=EDt=E1s hossza a "lag". A Newey-West akkor konzistens, ha &=
#34;lag"/T^{1/4} -> 0. Val=F3ban nem tudjuk, mi az optim=E1lis "=
lag" (mostan=E1ban fixed-b inferencia c=EDmen keresik ezt meg a kritiku=
s =E9rt=E9keket). A szoftverek gyakran floor(4*(T/100)^(2/9))-cel sz=E1moln=
ak (ami val=F3ban mondjuk 2-6 lag lesz =E1ltal=E1ban); de van 0.75*T^(1/3) =
is.

De igaz=E1b=F3l nincs k=F6ze a "full period of seasonal variation"-=
hoz, hiszen a hibatagnak stacion=E1risnak kell lennie, k=FCl=F6nben az eg=

Subject: New login to Twitter from 9.10.0 on Android
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

We're exploring a new=2C streamlined process that makes it easy for users=
 to report the findings of their study.=C2=A0

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/could-this-updated-registration-wo=
rkflow-help-you-1385380?e=3Deb5100a127)
Give feedback on a workflow that lets you link your findings with your reg=
istration
Hi G=C3=A1bor=2C

The Center for Open Science (COS) is working on a project called =E2=80=9C=
Community building and workflows for data sharing with publicly accessible=
 and consumable metadata=E2=80=9D which is supported by the EArly-concept=
 Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award from the National Science F=
oundation (NSF). Here=E2=80=99s the project overview to learn more if you=
 like: https://osf.io/kex5p/

Our team is exploring a workflow that makes it easy for researchers to rep=
ort the findings of their study. We are also looking at ways to intuitivel=
y upload=2C link=2C and share any documents=2C data=2C or resources that w=
ere generated from it.

We are seeking participants to engage in an hour long interview where they=
 will interact with and be asked questions about a prototype and its effec=
tiveness in their research workflow. The interview requires the use of a c=
omputer and screen sharing. The moderator will ask if the session can be v=
ideo recorded to review how the new process impacted your workflow. All in=
formation will be de-identified. If you have any questions=2C you can cont=
act Mark Call at mark@cos.io (mailto:mark@cos.io) .

Participants will be compensated with a $50 gift card after the interview=
 for their participation. If interested=2C sign up using our Calendly cale=
ndar (https://calendly.com/mark-1341/feedback-on-linking-study-findings-wi=
th-registration) .

We thank you for the valued feedback which is helping COS build the infras=
tructure and workflows to enable open practices.


Give feedback (https://calendly.com/mark-1341/feedback-on-linking-study-fi=
ndings-with-registration)

Subject: Fwd: New submission from Gabors Website Contact
New submission from Gabors Website Contact
Re: New submission from Gabors Website Contact
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Unlock OSF with a selection of resources custom-made for you

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/osf-tips-mar-1388047?e=3Deb5100a127)
Welcome to this month's edition of Tips & Tricks! Today=2C we=E2=80=99re d=
iving into a common concern among researchers: the fear of scooping=2C esp=
ecially when it comes to registering and sharing your work on the Open Sci=
ence Framework (OSF). Let's break it down and show you how OSF can help sa=
feguard your ideas while registering or preregistering your reaserch.
Fear of Scooping: What is Scooping?
"Scooping" refers to the worry that someone else might steal your research=
 idea and publish it before you. This concern is particularly acute when y=
ou=E2=80=99re thinking about registration or preregistration. Registering=
 your study means calling out your project idea before you start collectin=
g data=2C which might make you feel vulnerable to having that idea taken a=
nd used by someone else.

Why Embargo Your Preregistration on the OSF?
To address these concerns=2C the OSF offers an embargo option. Embargoing=
 your registration means that you can hide the details of your study from=
 public view for a certain period. This essentially makes your registratio=
n private for a period of time. This way=2C you can share your research pl=
an with the community and benefit from the transparency and credibility th=
at preregistration offers=2C without the fear of your idea being scooped.

When Can You Embargo a Preregistration?
You can choose to embargo your registration at the time of submission (htt=
ps://help.osf.io/article/164-submit-your-draft-registration#embargo?utm_so=
urce=3Dosfgenearl_enl&utm_medium=3Demail&utm_campaign=3Dtipstricks_june) .=
 This allows you to work on your project knowing that your research plan i=
s safely recorded and timestamped but not publicly accessible. You can als=
o end your embargo early at anytime (https://help.osf.io/article/151-end-a=
n-embargo-early?utm_source=3Dosfgenearl_enl&utm_medium=3Demail&utm_campaig=
n=3Dtipstricks_june) !

What Does an Embargo Look Like to the Outside World?
To outside viewers who do not have permission to access your embargoed reg=
istration=2C it will appear as a "page not found" notification. It=E2=80=
=99s as if your registration doesn=E2=80=99t exist=2C maintaining the conf=
identiality of your project until you=E2=80=99re ready to share it.

How Long Can an Embargo Last?
An embargo on the OSF can last for up to four years from the first submiss=
ion. This gives you ample time to complete your research and publish your=
 findings without worrying about your idea being prematurely disclosed.

In Summary
The fear of scooping is a valid concern=2C but with the OSF's embargo opti=
on=2C you can protect your research ideas while still enjoying the benefit=
s of preregistration. By choosing to embargo your registration=2C you are=
 given ample time to complete your study=2C while being given credit for y=
our original submission date. This gives you credit for transparency calli=
ng out your study plan while keeping privacy for your new ideas. If you ha=
ve more questions see our document on the benefits and potential concerns=
 of preregistations (https://help.osf.io/article/603-benefits-of-registrat=
ion?utm_source=3Dosfgenearl_enl&utm_medium=3Demail&utm_campaign=3Dtipstric=
ks_june) .

Want to learn more about using OSF to support sharing and discovery of you=
r research? Check out our upcoming OSF webinars!
https://cos-io.zoom.us/webinar/register/1917182945924/WN_b8pEtBbvSv2yu69ne=
dy5Pw

Sv2yu69nedy5Pw) for a webinar tailored to academic librarians and research=
 support staff. Explore OSF Institutions=2C a platform empowering open sch=
olarship practices within academic institutions.

searchers face throughout the research lifecycle=2C while also providing a=

Thank you for considering my request. I'll be teaching the undergraduate
course "Data Analytics for Economics and Business" starting next year,
syllabus here <https://guide.univpm.it/af.php?af=3D161584>.

reading for students approaching econometrics and data science.

I agree with the conditions on the website

Kind regards

Claudia Pigini

Universit=C3=A0 Politecnica delle Marche
Piazzale Martelli 8
60121 Ancona, Italy
Tel.: +39 071 2207103

Thanks a lot for your interest in our book, I'm glad you liked it.

Overleaf access is available for all adopters - see conditions at
https://gabors-data-analysis.com/overleaf-users

Have a look and if you agree, just email me, including a link to your
course or a link/copy of your syllabus, and I grant you access. (No need to
sign anything.)

Best
Gabors

rocess

or my own

project -

 as one's
>>>>>>>> understanding matures they are able to recognize when digressions =
from a
>>>>>>>> framework are warranted. But, for me at least, and particularly in=
 this

ess is

dology or
>>>>>>>> technique to use when.

ublished

who allow

orrode

rmed

n

on its

es me a

eam to

mention

mental

ng houses

rt to

pective

Subject: Re: New submission from Gabors Website Contact
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi Gabor,

I was working through the code in Chapter 11, and I might have found an
error. In the file "ch11-smoking-health-risk.R", on line 248, you give the
code for a multiple regression. However when I run the code below, on line
254 to add a variable for the predictions, I get an error message saying
the number of predictions is less than the number of cases in the file
"share". Upon checking, the regression actually threw an error: "163
observations deleted due to missingness". When I pulled these observations
each had an NA in one or another column.

I fixed this by adding "na.action=3Dna.exclude" to the original regression
and then it successfully added the variable with the predictions. Perhaps I
just missed some code I was supposed to run to get rid of the NAs, but
thought to let you know.

Matan

Subject: Re: Delivery Status Notification (Failure)
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi,

I do have one question about the methodology described in Chapter 10. I
learned to input a factor variable with different levels directly into a
regression formula (using lm() in R) and let R do the dummy coding. In the
results of such a regression, the level not appearing in the estimates is
the reference level, and the estimates of the other levels represent the
difference from the reference level.

In Chapter 10 however you illustrate dummy coding having separate variables
(for example in Case Study 10.B1 you create dichotomous variables for the
3.5 star variable and the 4 star variable. I've seen this method referred
to as "level means coding
<https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/94010/understanding-dummy-manual=
-or-automated-variable-creation-in-glm>".
That's fine, but in the Case Study description you mention that "3 stars is
the reference category."

In my understanding (which can certainly be flawed - you wrote the
textbook!=F0=9F=99=82) , the regression summary for this level means coding=
 shows an
estimate for each of the dichotomous variables, but the estimate is not the
difference from a reference category, but rather simply the Beta
coefficient for each of the variables (i.e. there is no reference
category). If that's indeed not the case, I don't understand how, in the
above case study, R would even determine that 3 stars is the reference
category as you create completely new variables to represent 3.5 and 4
stars (code below).

I'm sure I'm missing something but can't figure out what....

[image: Screen Shot 2022-12-27 at 11.07.19 PM.png]
[image: Screen Shot 2022-12-27 at 11.06.54 PM.png]
[image: Screen Shot 2022-12-27 at 11.07.50 PM.png]

n

>>> Hello.
>>>
>>> I'm now on Chapter 9 of your book (self study) and, after waiting for
>>> something that might change my opinion and not finding it, am ready to
>>> share my impression with you that you and your colleague have made a
>>> terrifically unique and important contribution to the data science/anal=
ysis
>>> literature. In fact, it could just be a reflection of the existing
>>> paradigm in which these subjects have been and are still being taught
>>> today, but I'm repeatedly surprised by the clarity and order brough to =
each
>>> subject by your book - a clarity and order I've never experienced - and
>>> always sought - from every other data analysis/statistics text/class I'=
ve
>>> utilized.
>>>
>>> I've complained for years to anyone who would listen =F0=9F=99=82 that =
I simply
>>> didn't understand why these subjects are taught as they are: as a
>>> collection of methods/calculations which address certain issues. My
>>> experience has been that this teaching paradigm both limits my
>>> understanding and recall of the use of these methods because there's no
>>> overarching structure within which I can understand their relevance. He=
re's
>>> a book on regression - OK, when do I use regression? Here's a book on
>>> confidence intervals - OK, when and why should I use them? I'm largely =
left
>>> to cobble together my own methodology. Your book however unifies these
>>> methods into an understandable process, allowing me to appreciate their
>>> relevance and use at different stages of a data analysis project. Becau=
se I
>>> understand their relevance, they make more sense to me and are more dee=
ply
>>> ingrained into my memory. And because I'm viewing a start-finish proces=
s
>>> which has some order and objective, I can utilize that framework for my=
 own
>>> data analysis projects. Of course I understand that no analytical proje=
ct -
>>> or any advanced methodology - can be a strictly A-to-Z affair, and as o=
ne's
>>> understanding matures they are able to recognize when digressions from =
a
>>> framework are warranted. But, for me at least, and particularly in this
>>> subject, a unified understanding of the objective and general process i=
s
>>> critical for me to be able to make informed choices of which methodolog=
y or
>>> technique to use when.
>>>
>>> Also, and I also can't emphasize this enough, there are no (OK, a coupl=
e
>>> of simple typos) errors!!!! This in an era when books are published wit=
h
>>> seemingly little to no editing! I don't know whether authors who allow
>>> their work to be published with errors understand how that might corrod=
e
>>> the confidence of their readers, but that's certainly the case for me. =
On a
>>> couple of occasions - perhaps trained by my prior textbooks - I've said=
 to
>>> myself, "ah - they forgot to mention that! Aha!", or "ah, they left out=
 a
>>> description of that just like all the other books!", only to find on th=
e
>>> next page I was wrong. So many things that I've found are completely ta=
ken
>>> for granted in other textbooks - weighting, rationale and nature of nat=
ural
>>> log transformations, use of regression residuals, even a simple
>>> understanding of the difference between parametric and nonparametric
>>> methods - are given thoughtful and clear treatment in your text (OK, I =
was
>>> a little confused - even though I see the details in the R code - of ho=
w
>>> one adds a natural log scale to an axis representing a log-transformed
>>> variable - but that's probably my lack of mathematical maturity).
>>>
>>> Finally, the R code! I read the text, then work through the code in R
>>> Studio, and the code is worth (more than) the price of the book on its =
own.
>>> Besides further enhancing my understanding of the text, it demonstrates
>>> good code-writing technique and R usage, and also gives me a plethora o=
f
>>> templates I can refer to in my own data analytics work. I'm thinking ab=
out
>>> how much effort it must have taken people on your team to develop the R
>>> visualization templates and all the R code - not to mention the code in=
 the
>>> other languages. It seems it must have been a monumental undertaking.
>>>
>>> In summary, I have tens, perhaps close to a hundred of the yellow
>>> Springer books and all their relatives from the different publishing ho=
uses
>>> adorning my walls and your text is the first to really make me start to
>>> feel (I'm only a third through the book) I can do this stuff on my own
>>> because I understand what I'm supposed to do - not a method or a techni=
que
>>> but an entire process and framework. My only question is: Why did you w=
rite
>>> the book you wrote? Why is your text so different from all the rest? Di=
d
>>> you recognize the need, or simply have a completely different perspecti=
ve
>>> from those before you? And what has been the reaction of the buying pub=
lic?
>>>
>>> Immeasurable thanks,
>>>
>>> Matan Gilbert
>>>
>>>

>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>

I just finished an Amazon review which I imagine will be available shortly.

Are you familiar with any resources offering multiple regression case
studies? Once I'm finished with the regression section of your book I'd
like to get practice on real data but with the addition of expert
commentary/insight/direction such as exists in your case studies so that I
can continue to refine my abilities.

Dear Matan

Thanks so much for this very kind review.

Our mission was to democratize data analysis. There is plenty of material
for phd programs with people with math background who study these topics
for many years. But we struggled to find stg for those who are smart, hard
working but want to learn 95% of the trade in 1-2ys. And 8ys later, we have
finished it....

And, the strategy was curated content + case studies. Yes massive team
effort on code base. (Check out our new online free code learning course!)

Oh there is plenty of errors (see errata...) but we had a text development
editor (=3D my wife...) who corrected thru 2x, checked all tables, etc  plu=
s
a language and copy editing from Cambridge.

A lot of it was self taught. Like i watched videos on graphics and vision
to make everything in viridis scheme.

I think our text is different because it is not written to get applause
from colleagues but help students in their journey.

So thanks again. If you could share this on amazon/social media, I'd
appreciate it.

Best
Gabor

Subject: New submission from Gabors Website Contact
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello.

I'm now on Chapter 9 of your book (self study) and, after waiting for
something that might change my opinion and not finding it, am ready to
share my impression with you that you and your colleague have made a
terrifically unique and important contribution to the data science/analysis
literature. In fact, it could just be a reflection of the existing
paradigm in which these subjects have been and are still being taught
today, but I'm repeatedly surprised by the clarity and order brough to each
subject by your book - a clarity and order I've never experienced - and
always sought - from every other data analysis/statistics text/class I've
utilized.

I've complained for years to anyone who would listen =F0=9F=99=82 that I si=
mply
didn't understand why these subjects are taught as they are: as a
collection of methods/calculations which address certain issues. My
experience has been that this teaching paradigm both limits my
understanding and recall of the use of these methods because there's no
overarching structure within which I can understand their relevance. Here's
a book on regression - OK, when do I use regression? Here's a book on
confidence intervals - OK, when and why should I use them? I'm largely left
to cobble together my own methodology. Your book however unifies these
methods into an understandable process, allowing me to appreciate their
relevance and use at different stages of a data analysis project. Because I
understand their relevance, they make more sense to me and are more deeply
ingrained into my memory. And because I'm viewing a start-finish process
which has some order and objective, I can utilize that framework for my own
data analysis projects. Of course I understand that no analytical project -
or any advanced methodology - can be a strictly A-to-Z affair, and as one's
understanding matures they are able to recognize when digressions from a
framework are warranted. But, for me at least, and particularly in this
subject, a unified understanding of the objective and general process is
critical for me to be able to make informed choices of which methodology or
technique to use when.

Also, and I also can't emphasize this enough, there are no (OK, a couple of
simple typos) errors!!!! This in an era when books are published with
seemingly little to no editing! I don't know whether authors who allow
their work to be published with errors understand how that might corrode
the confidence of their readers, but that's certainly the case for me. On a
couple of occasions - perhaps trained by my prior textbooks - I've said to
myself, "ah - they forgot to mention that! Aha!", or "ah, they left out a
description of that just like all the other books!", only to find on the
next page I was wrong. So many things that I've found are completely taken
for granted in other textbooks - weighting, rationale and nature of natural
log transformations, use of regression residuals, even a simple
understanding of the difference between parametric and nonparametric
methods - are given thoughtful and clear treatment in your text (OK, I was
a little confused - even though I see the details in the R code - of how
one adds a natural log scale to an axis representing a log-transformed
variable - but that's probably my lack of mathematical maturity).

Finally, the R code! I read the text, then work through the code in R
Studio, and the code is worth (more than) the price of the book on its own.
Besides further enhancing my understanding of the text, it demonstrates
good code-writing technique and R usage, and also gives me a plethora of
templates I can refer to in my own data analytics work. I'm thinking about
how much effort it must have taken people on your team to develop the R
visualization templates and all the R code - not to mention the code in the
other languages. It seems it must have been a monumental undertaking.

In summary, I have tens, perhaps close to a hundred of the yellow Springer
books and all their relatives from the different publishing houses adorning
my walls and your text is the first to really make me start to feel (I'm
only a third through the book) I can do this stuff on my own because I
understand what I'm supposed to do - not a method or a technique but an
entire process and framework. My only question is: Why did you write the
book you wrote? Why is your text so different from all the rest? Did you
recognize the need, or simply have a completely different perspective from
those before you? And what has been the reaction of the buying public?

Immeasurable thanks,

Matan Gilbert

Thanks so much for offering! This seems to be a problem with the
modelsummary package, as it's only happening on my Macbook Pro and not my
Windows machine. Unfortunately, I can't find any references to this issue
anywhere that might help me resolve it. There are of course alternatives
but having been introduced to it by your book I was looking forward to
using it.

Matan

Subject: Fwd: Slides
Slides
Text:
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

New policy to go into effect February 1=2C 2024

https://osf.io
View in browser (https://mailchi.mp/osf/affiliate-your-osf-research-with-u=
md-1386792?e=3Deb5100a127)
OSF Preprints to Implement
Pre-Moderation Policy

Hello=2C valued user=2C

COS is proud to provide the OSF Preprints (https://osf.io/preprints/) serv=
ice as an open archive that provides a free=2C open access platform for sc=
holars to upload working papers=2C preprints=2C and published papers=2C wi=
th the ability to link data and code.

After a successful Post-Moderation trial=2C COS has decided to move to ado=
pt a Pre-Moderation policy (http://pre-moderation) starting February 1=2C=
 2024. This will ensure that content would not need to be withdrawn. Expec=
tations are that preprints would be moderated within 1-2 business days. Pr=
e-moderated preprints are not made public immediately. They will only be i=
ndexed and assigned a digital object identifier (DOI) once they are accept=
ed by a moderator and published. Authors will be given notice of reasoning=
 behind any preprints that are not accepted.

This policy is meant to maintain a low barrier to entry with open scholars=
hip practices=2C with an easy preprint submission workflow while minimizin=
g exploitation by individuals or groups potentially seeking to gamify scho=
larly impact systems. Preprints will continue to be public immediately upo=
n submission=2C with the potential for removal if the content does not mee=
t OSF Preprint content policies. You can read more about the OSF Preprints=
 moderation policies on the OSF Support Center (https://help.osf.io/articl=
e/592-preprint-moderation) .

This change in policy will ensure the advancement of the COS mission to de=
mocratize access to research and expand sharing of all research content wh=
ile maintaining the integrity of content on the OSF Preprint server. Thank=
 you for your support of OSF and open science=2C and please reach out to u=
s at support@cos.io (mailto:support@cos.io) if you have any questions.


Best=2C

Center for Open Science Team

message:
On Pg 376, eq 13.8, I think there is an error in the formula
for the Variance, it should be
\hat y_j - \bar\hat y_j
rather than=20
y_j - \bar\hat y_j
